Name: John Herschel
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his paper on nebulae and clusters of stars, published in the Philosophical Transactions for 1833

Name: James Sylvester
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his various memoirs and researches in mathematical science

Name: John Newport Langley
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his work on secreting glands, and on the nervous system

Name: Charles Pritchard
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his work on photometry and stellar parallax

Name: Arthur Schuster
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his spectroscopic inquiries, and his researches on disruptive discharge through gases and on terrestrial magnetism

Name: Percy MacMahon
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For the number and range of his contributions to mathematical science

Name: William Burnside
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his researches in mathematics, particularly in the theory of groups

Name: Augustus Love
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: On the ground of his researches in the theory of elasticity and cognate subjects

Name: William Mitchinson Hicks
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: On the ground of his researches in mathematical physics

Name: Grafton Elliot Smith
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: No citation.

Name: William Johnson Sollas
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For researches in palaeontology

Name: Joseph Larmor
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: On the ground of his numerous and important contributions to mathematical and physical science

Name: William Rivers
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: On the ground of his important contributions to ethnography and ethnology

Name: William Bateson
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: On the ground of his contributions to biological science, and especially his studies in genetics

Name: Frederick Blackman
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his researches on the gaseous exchange in plants & on the operation of limiting factors

Name: Albert Seward
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his researches on the palaeobotany of Gondwanaland

Name: John Edward Marr
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his pioneer work in the accurate zoning of the palaeozoic rocks

Name: Patrick Laidlaw
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his work on diseases due to viruses, including that on the cause and prevention of distemper in dogs.

Name: Alfred Harker
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his distinguished work and influence as a petrologist

Name: Paul Dirac
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For the leading part he had taken in the development of the new quantum mechanics

Name: William Topley
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his outstanding work on experimental epidemiology and immunology

Name: Harold Jeffreys
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his distinguished work in geophysics and his important contributions to the astronomy of the solar system

Name: Edward Appleton
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his work on the ele [sic] transmission of electromagnetic waves round the earth and for his investigations of the ionic state of the upper atmosphere

Name: Frederic Bartlett
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his creation of an experimental school of psychology which has established under his leadership an outstanding position recognised internationally as without superior

Name: Nevill Mott
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his eminent work in the field of quantum theory and particularly in the theory of metals

Name: John Cockcroft
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his distinguished work on nuclear and atomic physics

Name: W. V. D. Hodge
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his distinguished work on algebraic geometry

Name: Rudolf Peierls
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his distinguished work on the theoretical foundations of high energy and nuclear physics

Name: Raymond Lyttleton
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his distinguished contributions to astronomy, particularly for his work on the dynamical stability of galaxies

Name: Frank Yates
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his profound and far-reaching contributions to the statistical methods of experimental biology

Name: Joseph Hutchinson
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his distinguished work on the genetics and evolution of crop-plants with particular reference to cotton

Name: Charles Oatley
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his distinguished work in the wartime development of radar and latterly for the design and development of a highly successful scanning electron microscope

Name: Frederick Sanger
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his pioneer work on the sequence of amino acids in proteins and of nucleotides of ribonucleic acids

Name: Fred Hoyle
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his distinguished contributions to theoretical physics and cosmology

Name: Abdus Salam
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his outstanding contributions to the physics of elementary particles with special reference to the unification of the electromagnetic and weak interactions

Name: Roger Penrose
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his fundamental contributions to the theory of gravitational collapse and to other geometric aspects of theoretical physics

Name: Eric Denton
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his outstanding contributions to the physiology of marine animals, to marine biology generally, and his leadership of UK marine science

Name: Robert Hinde
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: In recognition of his contributions to the field of animal behaviour and the dominant influence it achieved on the emerging field of ethology

Name: Christopher Dobson
Rationale[28][29][30][31][32]: For his outstanding contributions to the understanding of the mechanisms of protein folding and mis-folding, and the implications for disease
